questions.text: A patient presents with a large, deep wound and the healthcare provider decides to use a specific wound-healing procedure. What is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative pressure wound therapy

 

Negative pressure wound therapy, also known as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy, involves the application of negative pressure to a wound using a sealed dressing connected to a vacuum pump.

 

  • This therapy helps in wound healing by several mechanisms: it removes excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound, improves blood flow to the area, reduces edema (swelling), and promotes the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It is often used for large, deep wounds, chronic wounds, and complex surgical wounds to accelerate the healing process.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

VAC therapy = vacuum assisted closure therapy

 

  1. Mechanism of action: VAC therapy involves the application of negative pressure (-125 mm of hg) to a wound to promote wound healing. The negative pressure removes excess fluid and promotes the formation of granulation tissue and new blood vessels.
  2. Indications: VAC therapy is commonly used for the management of complex wounds, such as diabetic foot ulcers, pressure ulcers, and surgical wounds. It can also be used to manage wounds with high risk of infection.
  3. Procedure: VAC therapy involves placing a foam dressing over the wound and covering it with an adhesive film. A tube is then inserted through the film and connected to a vacuum pump, which applies negative pressure to the wound. The pressure can be adjusted to provide the optimal level of tension for the specific wound.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Morrison retractor

 

  • The Morrison retractor is a surgical instrument used in abdominal surgery to retract the liver and expose the retroperitoneal space.
  • The instrument consists of two curved blades that are inserted through a small incision in the abdominal wall and positioned over the liver.
  • The blades are then spread apart to provide a clear view of the surgical field.

 

Option A. Deaver's
 

Broad handheld retractor for large abdominal/thoracic incisions.

 

 

Option C. Czerny’s

 

 

Option D. Double Hook

 

 

Educational Objective:


The Morrison retractor is used during abdominal surgeries, specifically to retract the liver and expose the retroperitoneal space.

choices.text: Interference with implantation of the fertilized ovum

questions.text: All of the following mechanisms of action of oral contraceptive pills are true, except: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Interference with placental functioning

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) primarily work through three mechanisms:

 

  1. Inhibition of ovulation: Progesterone in the pills reduces the frequency of luteinizing hormone (LH) secretory pulses, and estrogen reduces follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion. Together, they prevent the midcycle LH surge, thus inhibiting ovulation.
  2. Prevention of fertilization: The cervical mucus is thickened, creating a hostile environment for sperm, which inhibits fertilization. Additionally, uterine and tubal contractions are altered to prevent fertilization.
  3. Interference with implantation: OCPs cause changes in the endometrium, making it hyperproliferative, hypersecretory, or atrophic and out of phase with the ovulatory cycle, rendering it unsuitable for the implantation of a fertilized ovum.

 

OCPs do not interfere with placental functioning, as their primary purpose is to prevent pregnancy before implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of ovulation: This is one of the primary mechanisms of action of OCPs.

 

Option B. Prevention of fertilization: This mechanism involves creating a hostile environment for sperm and altering uterine contractions to prevent fertilization.

 

Option C. Interference with implantation of the fertilized ovum: This is achieved by altering the endometrial lining, making it unsuitable for implantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral contraceptive pills prevent pregnancy through inhibition of ovulation, prevention of fertilization, and interference with implantation but do not affect placental function.

choices.text: Commonly presents as an abdominal mass
Presents in children < 6 years of age
Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

questions.text: Which of these is incorrect about Wilms’ tumor? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lung metastasis is rare and seen as a late feature

 

Wilms’ tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is a type of kidney cancer that primarily affects children, typically under the age of six. It is one of the most common pediatric solid tumors and presents with a variety of clinical features, most notably an abdominal mass.

 

  • Common Presentation: The most common presenting symptom of Wilms’ tumor is a painless abdominal mass, which may be noticed by the child's parents or during a routine physical examination. This aligns with option A, making it correct.
  • Age of Onset: Wilms’ tumor most frequently occurs in young children, particularly those under the age of six. This is well-documented in clinical practice and research, making option B correct.
  • Treatment and Prognosis: The treatment for Wilms’ tumor typically includes a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and sometimes radiotherapy. The majority of patients have a good prognosis and can recover with appropriate treatment, supporting option C as correct.
  • Lung Metastasis: Contrary to option D, lung metastasis is actually relatively common in Wilms’ tumor and often one of the first sites of metastasis. It is not rare, nor is it necessarily a late feature. Early detection and treatment of lung metastases are crucial in the management of Wilms' tumor, making this option incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Commonly presents as an abdominal mass: This is a correct statement. Wilms’ tumor typically presents as an abdominal mass, which is often the first sign that prompts further investigation.

 

Option B. Presents in children < 6 years of age: This is also correct. The majority of cases occur in children under the age of six, making this a well-recognized feature of the disease.

 

Option C. Majority of patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy: This statement is accurate as well. Advances in chemotherapy and radiotherapy have significantly improved survival rates for patients with Wilms’ tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lung metastasis in Wilms’ tumor is not rare; it is actually a common site of metastasis and often occurs early in the disease course.

questions.text: Patient presents with urinary complaints with sterile pyuria on urine-analysis. A cystoscopy shows dilated ureteric orifice. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Golf hole ureteric orifice

 

The clinical scenario describes a patient with urinary complaints and sterile pyuria, a condition where white blood cells are present in the urine without bacterial infection. The cystoscopy reveals a dilated ureteric orifice, which is characteristic of a golf hole ureteric orifice. This condition can occur due to functional obstruction or vesicoureteral reflux, where the ureteric orifice becomes dilated and appears abnormal on cystoscopy.

 

The key diagnostic clue here is the sterile pyuria combined with the specific appearance of the ureteric orifice on cystoscopy, pointing directly to a golf hole ureteric orifice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bladder diverticuli: Bladder diverticuli are pouches that form on the bladder wall and would appear as sac-like outpouchings rather than a dilated ureteric orifice. They are not typically associated with sterile pyuria.

 

Option C. Bladder ulcer: Bladder ulcers are characterized by mucosal erosions within the bladder and do not present with a dilated ureteric orifice. They may cause hematuria and pain rather than sterile pyuria.

 

Option D. Cystitis: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often due to infection. It typically presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. In cystitis, cystoscopy would show diffuse bladder wall inflammation rather than a dilated ureteric orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dilated ureteric orifice seen on cystoscopy in a patient with sterile pyuria is indicative of a golf hole ureteric orifice, a condition where the orifice is abnormally dilated, often due to reflux or functional obstruction.

choices.text: Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome
Chest Xray is the investigation of choice

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding thymoma? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common neoplasm of thymus

 

Thymomas are indeed the most common primary tumors of the thymus. These tumors originate from the epithelial cells of the thymus, an organ located in the anterior mediastinum. While they can be associated with various systemic syndromes, particularly myasthenia gravis, they may also be asymptomatic and are sometimes discovered incidentally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common posterior mediastinal tumor: This statement is incorrect. Thymomas are tumors of the anterior mediastinum, not the posterior. Neurogenic tumors are the most common tumors in the posterior mediastinum.

 

Option C. Usually symptomatic with dyspnoea, dysphagia and SVC syndrome: Thymomas can be asymptomatic or they may present with symptoms due to compression of nearby structures. While they can cause symptoms like dyspnea (shortness of breath) if they compress the trachea or lungs, or symptoms of Superior Vena Cava (SVC) syndrome if they compress the SVC, these are not the most common presentations. The association with systemic syndromes like myasthenia gravis is more characteristic.

 

Option D. Chest Xray is the investigation of choice: While a chest X-ray can identify a mediastinal mass suggesting a thymoma, a computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest is usually the investigation of choice for further characterization and to evaluate the exact size, location, and any local invasion. The CT scan provides more detailed images than a simple chest X-ray.

questions.text: Modified shock index is calculated using? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HR/MAP

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

 

A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

 

HR: Heart rate

 

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

 

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

 

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure

 

# Commonly confused:

 

Formula for shock index= Heart rate/ systolic blood pressure

 

Educational Objective :

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency department with sudden hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peptic ulcer

 

  • This patient most likely has a bleeding peptic ulcer.
  •  Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) includes both gastric and duodenal ulcers.
  •  Aspirin, an NSAID, interferes with the protective role of prostaglandins on the gastric and duodenal mucosa, increasing the risk of peptic ulcer formation in the stomach and the duodenum.
  •  Common presentations of peptic ulcers include pain in the epigastrium, bleeding, and vomiting.
  • The history of aspirin use and alcohol consumption further supports the diagnosis of a peptic ulcer.

 

Peptic Ulcer Disease (PUD)

 

  • Etiology: Helicobacter pylori infection and NSAID use.
  • Mechanism: NSAIDs like aspirin disrupt the protective mucosal layer, leading to ulcer formation.
  • Symptoms: Epigastric pain, hematemesis, melena.
  • Sequelae:
    • Bleeding (more common in duodenal ulcers)
    • Perforation leading to peritonitis
    • Stricture causing gastric outlet obstruction
    • Malignancy risk (only in gastric ulcers)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss:

 

  • Occurs following repeated vomiting or retching, often associated with an alcoholic binge.
  • Characterized by mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Presents with self-limiting hematemesis, not usually profuse.

 

Option B. Esophagitis:

 

  • Inflammation of the esophagus, often due to gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Results in chronic blood loss and commonly presents as anemia rather than sudden hematemesis.
  • Symptoms include heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia.

 

Option D. Esophageal varices:

 

  • Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus, often due to portal hypertension.
  • Common in patients with liver cirrhosis.
  • Presents with massive hematemesis, splenomegaly, and ascites, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is a common cause of sudden hematemesis, especially in patients with risk factors such as NSAID use (e.g., aspirin) and occasional alcohol consumption.
  • Recognition of these risk factors is crucial in diagnosing and managing PUD effectively.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient is referred to a neurologist with complaints of facial flushing and sweating while eating or even just thinking about food. The patient reports that this has been happening for several months and is becoming increasingly bothersome. Upon further questioning, the patient also reports a history of parotid gland surgery for a benign tumor several years ago. Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

Frey's syndrome is a rare condition that occurs as a complication of parotid gland surgery or other trauma to the area. It is characterized by facial flushing and sweating in the region of the face associated with the parotid gland, particularly when eating or thinking about food. The underlying cause of Frey's syndrome is damage to the auriculotemporal nerve (a branch of the mandibular nerve, V3). This damage results in abnormal nerve regeneration and cross-connection between the parasympathetic fibers that stimulate salivation and the sympathetic fibers that control sweating.

 

  • Mechanism: The auriculotemporal nerve contains both sensory fibers and parasympathetic secretomotor fibers that supply the parotid gland. Following injury or surgery, these fibers can aberrantly regenerate, causing parasympathetic fibers to innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin, leading to sweating and flushing upon salivation.

 

Treatment Options:

 

  • Topical Antiperspirants: These can help reduce sweating by blocking sweat glands.
  • Oral Medications: Medications that reduce sweating may be prescribed.
  • Botulinum Toxin Injections: These injections can block the action of sweat glands, providing relief from symptoms.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve: The facial nerve controls facial expressions and can be injured during parotid surgery, leading to facial palsy. However, it is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option B. Oculomotor nerve: The oculomotor nerve controls eye movements and pupil constriction and is not involved in the innervation of the parotid gland or the region affected in Frey's syndrome.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is involved in taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue and parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland. However, it is not directly involved in the facial flushing and sweating characteristic of Frey's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey's syndrome is caused by damage to the auriculotemporal nerve, leading to abnormal sweating and flushing of the face associated with eating or thinking about food. This condition is a common complication of parotid gland surgery.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the newborn baby as shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate anus

 

The given investigation is invertogram. It is done 6-12 hours after birth. It is done for anorectal malformations (ARM). Gap between the gas and coin measured, if it is >2 cm we suspect abnormalities proximal to pelvic floor, like rectal atresia (high ARM). If gap is < 2cm, the ARM is low, and restricted only to anal defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningocele is a type of neural tube defect that occurs during fetal development. It is attributed to the maternal folic acid deficiency. It involves protrusion of the meninges through a defect in the skull or vertebra. It is asymptomatic and mainly presents with a tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region.

 

Option B. Congenital Mega-colon is also known as Hirschsprung disease. It is congenital condition that occurs due to absence of ganglion cells in the colonic segment. The affected segment fails to relax, while the portion proximal to it becomes dilated.

 

Option D. Pyloric stenosis is a condition that affects the newborn and infants. It involves the hypertrophy of the pylorus leading to gastric outlet obstruction. The patient presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting with dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An invertogram performed 6-12 hours after birth is used to diagnose anorectal malformations in newborns by measuring the distance between a gas bubble in the rectum and a coin marker on the perineum.

questions.text: Which of the following method is shown in the surgical procedure to close the abdominal wound with the help of a mesh? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Onlay

 

The image shows a mesh placed over the abdominal muscles to close a wound, which is indicative of the onlay method. In the onlay technique, the mesh is placed on top of the rectus sheath and anterior abdominal wall muscles. This is typically used in open ventral hernia repairs where the mesh is laid directly on top of the closed fascial layer. This method is chosen for its simplicity and effectiveness in reinforcing the abdominal wall from the outside.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sublay: In this method, the mesh is placed beneath the rectus muscles but above the peritoneum. It is also known as the retromuscular or sublay position. This is not the method shown in the image.

 

Option C. Inlay: This method involves placing the mesh between the edges of the defect without overlapping. This is generally used when the defect cannot be closed primarily. The image does not show this technique.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal (Underlay): In this method, the mesh is placed inside the peritoneal cavity in direct contact with the abdominal organs. The image does not show this; instead, it shows the mesh being placed on top of the abdominal wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The onlay method involves placing the mesh on top of the abdominal muscles and rectus sheath, commonly used in open ventral hernia repairs.

questions.text: Pain in the right upper quadrant due to adhesions and inflammation between the liver and the diaphragm is known as: (NEET PG 2014 )
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is characterized by acute perihepatitis, which involves localized inflammation between the liver and the diaphragm. This condition is often a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), usually caused by the pathogen Chlamydia trachomatis. The inflammation leads to adhesions between the liver capsule (Glisson capsule) and the diaphragm, resulting in severe right upper quadrant pain that can mimic acute cholecystitis. Additional symptoms may include fever, leucocytosis, abdominal pain, cervicitis, and mildly elevated liver transaminases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mittelschmerz Syndrome: This syndrome refers to the ovulation pain experienced by some women around the middle of their menstrual cycle. The pain is typically one-sided and occurs due to the release of an egg from the ovary.

 

Option B. Mirizzi Syndrome: This condition involves the obstruction of the common hepatic duct due to external compression from a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or Hartmann's pouch of the gallbladder, leading to jaundice and cholangitis.

 

Option C. Asherman’s syndrome: Also known as Fritsch syndrome, this condition is characterized by the formation of intrauterine adhesions, often resulting from endometrial curettage, and typically presents as secondary amenorrhea or reduced menstrual flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is identified by acute perihepatitis causing right upper quadrant pain due to adhesions and inflammation between the liver and the diaphragm, often associated with pelvic inflammatory disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

choices.text: Mass as shown should be removed
Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done
Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done
Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the patient who presented with the following as shown in the image. Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

 

The patient presents with an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, as indicated by the previously reducible abdominal mass that has now become irreducible. This condition necessitates surgical intervention. The correct management involves reducing the hernia, repairing the defect with a mesh to prevent recurrence, and excising the redundant skin, especially if it appears stretched, unhealthy, or ulcerated. This comprehensive approach ensures both the structural repair and the removal of any compromised skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass as shown should be removed: Simply removing the mass without addressing the hernia repair and the redundant skin does not resolve the underlying issue and may lead to recurrence or complications.

 

Option B. Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done: While this option addresses the hernia reduction and repair, it does not consider the removal of unhealthy or redundant skin, which is necessary in cases of long-standing hernias with poor skin quality.

 

Option C. Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done: Anatomical repair alone, without the use of mesh, is less effective for ventral hernias and has a higher risk of recurrence. Mesh repair is the standard approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, the recommended treatment includes hernia reduction, mesh repair, and excision of redundant or unhealthy skin to ensure a durable and effective repair.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for GERD? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring

 

GERD has triad of retrosternal heart burn, epigastric pain and regurgitation. Investigation of choice for GERD: 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy: While it can visualize the damage or inflammation caused by GERD (like esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus), it doesn't provide direct evidence of acid reflux. It's useful for assessing complications or when GERD symptoms are severe.

 

Option C. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): Beneficial in evaluating hiatus hernias.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): It doesn't directly measure acid reflux or its effects on the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for diagnosing GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) is 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

questions.text: A bus conductor presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP (Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C2

 

Explanation:

 

The CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders categorizes the severity of venous disease based on clinical signs, etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology. In this system, the "C" (Clinical) classification is particularly useful for describing the visible and palpable signs of venous disease.

  • C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.
  • C1: Telangiectasias or reticular veins.
  • C2: Varicose veins. This stage is characterized by dilated, tortuous veins that are generally more than 3 mm in diameter, such as the 4 mm veins described in the patient's case.
  • C3: Edema related to venous disease.

 

Given the description of dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm, the patient's condition corresponds to C2 in the CEAP classification, indicating the presence of varicose veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C0: C0 indicates no visible or palpable signs of venous disease, which does not apply to this patient who has visible varicose veins.

 

Option B. C1: C1 indicates the presence of telangiectasias or reticular veins, which are smaller than 3 mm in diameter. This stage does not describe the 4 mm varicose veins observed in this patient.

 

Option D. C3: C3 is used to classify edema related to chronic venous disorders. This does not match the presentation of dilated, tortuous veins without mentioned edema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of dilated, tortuous veins larger than 3 mm, such as the 4 mm veins observed in the patient's foot, corresponds to stage C2 in the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, indicating varicose veins.

questions.text: Identify the lesion as shown in the image below? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neuropathic ulcer

 

  • The provided image indicates the presence of a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Neuropathic ulcers, also known as trophic ulcers, are the result of nerve damage, typically in individuals with conditions like diabetes or peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are often painless and can develop on the soles of the feet or other areas subject to pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arterial insufficiency: Arterial insufficiency ulcers are typically caused by poor blood circulation, often due to arterial disease. They often occur on the feet, toes, or lower legs and can appear as painful, pale wounds with well-defined edges. Other signs of ischemia are seen

 

 

Option C. Venous ulcers: Venous ulcers are typically caused by venous insufficiency, which leads to poor blood circulation in the legs. These ulcers often appear near the ankles and are characterized by swelling, redness, and sometimes pain.

 

 

Option D. Tuberculous ulcers: Tuberculous ulcers are a manifestation of tuberculosis infection in the skin. They are characterized by the presence of nodules or ulcers with undermined edges and a necrotic center.

 

 

Tuberculous ulcer with typical bluish undermined margins overlying sternal tuberculosis focus  

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neuropathic ulcers result from peripheral neuropathy, where lack of sensation over pressure points leads to unnoticed minor wounds or cuts, eventually developing into ulcers.
  • Features of neuropathic ulcers include painless, punched out ulcers with regular margins, commonly located on the plantar surface of the foot.
  • Ulcer margins show the presence of calluses.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD complaining of swelling in the neck region, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is the correct treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk procedure

 

The clinical presentation of a neck swelling that moves with deglutition (swallowing) and protrusion of the tongue is highly suggestive of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This congenital anomaly arises from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which can form cysts anywhere along the duct's path from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland.

 

The definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, whether it is inflamed, ruptured, or has formed a fistula, is the Sistrunk procedure. This surgical procedure involves the removal of the cyst along with the entire thyroglossal tract and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be necessary if there is an infection, they do not treat the underlying cyst and would not prevent recurrence.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This approach may be used if there is an abscess formation, but it is not definitive treatment and would not prevent recurrence of the cyst or fistula.

 

Option D. Excision: Simple excision of the cyst alone is not sufficient as it does not remove the entire thyroglossal tract or part of the hyoid bone, leading to a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk procedure is the definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the excision of the cyst, the entire thyroglossal tract, and part of the hyoid bone to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with septic shock. The physician decides to administer vasopressors to manage the patient's condition. The patient also requires multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access. A central venous catheter is inserted into the patient's internal jugular vein. Which of the following statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous access and their associated complications? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.
  2. Flushing with isotonic saline and heparin can maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, peripheral venous access should be avoided in that same limb.
  4. Vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 is true as phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.

 

Statement 2 is also true as flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is used to maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.

 

Statement 3 is true as the presence of an arteriovenous fistula in a limb is a relative contraindication for peripheral venous access in that same limb.

 

Statement 4 is also true as vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.

 

In this clinical case, the patient's septic shock required vasopressors, and multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access, leading to the insertion of a central venous catheter into the internal jugular vein. To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin, vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic shock is a life-threatening medical condition that occurs as a result of a severe infection leading to a systemic inflammatory response. It is characterized by a combination of infection, low blood pressure (hypotension), and organ dysfunction. Here are some key points about septic shock:

 

  1. Infection: Septic shock typically begins with an infection, often caused by bacteria, but it can also result from fungal or viral infections. Common sources of infection include lung infections (pneumonia), urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and skin infections.
  2. Systemic Inflammatory Response: In response to the infection, the body's immune system initiates a widespread inflammatory response. This response can become dysregulated, leading to an exaggerated release of inflammatory molecules (cytokines) into the bloodstream.
  3. Hypotension: One of the hallmark features of septic shock is low blood pressure (hypotension). The inflammation and vasodilation caused by the infection can lead to a drop in blood pressure, which can result in inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
  4. Organ Dysfunction: As blood pressure drops and organs receive less oxygen and nutrients, multiple organ systems can begin to fail. This can lead to dysfunction in the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and other organs. Organ dysfunction is a critical component of septic shock and contributes to its high mortality rate.
  5. Symptoms: Symptoms of septic shock can include fever or hypothermia (low body temperature), rapid heart rate, rapid breathing, confusion, altered mental status, and signs of organ dysfunction such as respiratory distress, kidney failure, or liver dysfunction.
  6. Treatment: The treatment of septic shock is a medical emergency and involves aggressive interventions. It typically includes antibiotics to treat the underlying infection, intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, vasopressor medications to constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure, and supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)
Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was brought to the ER after RTA, her RR is 22/min, BP is 90/60mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the right side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What would be the appropriate management in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS followed by an intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

 

The given scenario of tachypnea, hypotension, hyper-resonance and x ray showing absent right broncho-vascular markings is suggestive of tension pneumothorax.

 

This option correctly addresses the likely diagnosis of a pneumothorax. The initial needle insertion can decompress the tension pneumothorax, and subsequent placement of an intercostal drain allows for continuous drainage of pleural air or fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS: This option suggests inserting a needle into the 5th ICS to relieve tension pneumothorax, which can occur due to trauma. While this can be a life-saving procedure, the presence of hyper-resonance on examination suggests a pneumothorax, but it does not address the drainage of pleural fluid, which is the primary concern in this case.

 

Option C. Aspiration of the pleural fluid: Aspiration of pleural fluid may be indicated in cases of pleural effusion, but it does not address the likely pneumothorax seen in this patient's presentation.

 

Option D. No intervention needed: With the patient's clinical presentation, including respiratory distress, low blood pressure, and hyper-resonance, intervention is indeed needed. Failure to intervene could lead to worsening respiratory compromise and potentially life-threatening consequences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension pneumothorax usually occurs due to trauma, such as a rib fracture, a puncture wound, or chest surgery, but it can also develop spontaneously in patients with underlying lung diseases, such as emphysema or cystic fibrosis.
  • Immediate treatment of tension pneumothorax is essential to prevent respiratory and cardiac arrest. The first step is to perform needle decompression, which involves inserting a large-bore needle into the affected side of the chest to release the trapped air in the triangle of safety. After that, a chest tube is inserted to further drain the air and prevent the reoccurrence of a pneumothorax.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for the daily use
Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient, who underwent midline laparotomy for colonic cancer one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible midline incisional hernia of 12cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair 

 

For a patient with a palpable abdominal bulge at the site of a recent surgical incision, indicative of an incisional hernia, management options vary depending on the size of the hernia, symptoms, and the patient's overall health status. 

 

This is a minimally invasive approach that is commonly used for large ventral hernias like in this case. The use of mesh is associated with a lower rate of recurrence compared to suture repair alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use: While an abdominal belt or binder can provide temporary relief and support for a hernia, it does not correct the underlying issue. It is more of a conservative approach and may be considered in patients who are not candidates for surgery.

 

Option C. Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months: Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic hernias or in patients where surgery poses a high risk. However, given the size of the hernia (12 cm), this approach could lead to an increased risk of complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic closure without mesh: Closing the hernia laparoscopically without mesh is less favored for larger hernias due to higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a large, reducible midline incisional hernia is to schedule a laparoscopic mesh repair, which offers a minimally invasive approach with a lower risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text:
What procedures are carried out during Breast Conservation Surgery? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Wide local excision
  2. Axillary node dissection
  3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery
  4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

1. Wide local excision:

 

  • This involves the removal of the breast tumor and a margin of surrounding normal tissue. The goal is to ensure that no cancer cells remain at the site, while preserving as much of the breast's appearance and function as possible.

 

2. Axillary node dissection:

 

  • This procedure involves removing lymph nodes from the axilla to check for the spread of cancer. If the sentinel lymph node biopsy (a procedure to remove the first node(s) that breast cancer is likely to spread) shows cancer, more extensive lymph node surgery might be done.

 

3. Frozen section (biopsy) to be done during surgery:

 

  • A frozen section involves rapidly freezing a tissue sample from the patient during surgery. A pathologist then examines the tissue under a microscope. This procedure allows for an immediate diagnosis, which can guide surgical decisions during the procedure, such as whether wider excision is needed if margins are not clear.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Post-operative radiotherapy is optional:

 

  • This statement is incorrect in the context of Breast Conservation Surgery (BCS). Post-operative radiotherapy is essential after BCS to reduce the risk of local recurrence of the tumor in the preserved breast tissue. It is not optional; rather, it's a standard part of the treatment plan in most cases.

 

Breast Conservative Therapy (BCT) consists of:

 

a. Wide local excision (>1cm) of tumor

 

b. Sentinel lymph node biopsy (if clinically node negative)

 

c. Post-operative radiotherapy – given in all cases of BCT

 

d. If pre-operative axillary LN metastasis is present, no need for sentinel lymph node biopsy. Up front axillary lymphadenectomy is done along with wide local excision of tumor.

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4

 

The image depicts a Stage 4 pressure ulcer (bedsore), which is characterized by deep tissue loss that exposes underlying structures such as muscle, bone, or supporting tissues. Stage 4 is the most severe form of pressure ulcer, often showing significant tissue necrosis, deep crater formation, and the possibility of undermining or tunneling under the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Stage 4 pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with visible muscle, bone, or supporting structures, making them the most severe and challenging to manage.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with an extremely painful blister characterized by a woody surface. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Necrotizing fasciitis

 

The elderly patient presents with an extremely painful lower limb blister characterized by a woody surface, which is indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe, rapidly progressing infection of the fascial planes that leads to tissue necrosis. It commonly affects the elderly or those with compromised immune systems and can follow trivial trauma. The infection begins in the fascia and subcutaneous tissue and can quickly spread, leading to gangrene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gas gangrene: This is incorrect as gas gangrene typically presents with a history of trauma or puncture wounds, and the presence of crepitus (air pockets) in the tissue, which is not described here.

 

Option B. Cellulitis: This is incorrect as cellulitis is an inflammation of the subcutaneous fat, usually without the formation of blisters or a woody texture, and it is not typically as painful as described.

 

Option D. DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis): This is incorrect as DVT presents with limb swelling and pain but does not cause blistering or a woody surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing fasciitis is a severe infection that affects the fascia and subcutaneous tissues, leading to extreme pain, blistering, and a woody surface, and requires prompt medical attention.

choices.text: Stop tobacco and don’t worry about the patch
Chemical cauterization with trichloroacetic acetic acid

questions.text: A chronic tobacco chewer presents with left cheek swelling. On examination a white membrane is seen over the gingiva buccal fold, which doesn’t get rubbed off. What will be your next line of management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical excision and biopsy

 

The patient is likely suffering from leukoplakia in the buccal mucosa. In such cases, a biopsy is crucial to rule out malignancy. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, so direct excision and biopsy are the most appropriate first steps to determine the nature of the lesion and guide further management.

 

Surgical Excision and Biopsy:

 

  • This is the preferred step when dealing with potential premalignant or malignant lesions like leukoplakia. It helps to both treat the lesion (by removing it) and diagnose its exact nature (via the biopsy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop Tobacco and Don’t Worry About the Patch: While quitting tobacco is always beneficial, merely stopping without addressing the lesion can be risky. Leukoplakia can have a significant rate of malignant transformation, and leaving it untreated without proper diagnosis could lead to missed early cancer detection.

 

Option C. Chemical Cauterization with Trichloroacetic Acid: Trichloroacetic acid (TCA) is an agent used for chemical cauterization. It has been used for benign lesions, warts, and certain other conditions, but it’s not the primary method of treatment for suspicious lesions like leukoplakia. Proper histopathological diagnosis is essential before considering treatment options.

 

Option D. MVAC Chemotherapy: MVAC is a chemotherapy regimen that includes Methotrexate, Vinblastine, Doxorubicin (Adriamycin), and Cisplatin. This regimen is typically used for treating advanced bladder cancer. It’s not a frontline treatment for an undiagnosed white patch in the oral cavity like leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukoplakia can potentially transform into a malignancy, and thus, any suspicious lesion in the oral cavity should be excised and biopsied for a definitive diagnosis and to rule out cancer.

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

 

The given clinical scenario suggests Acute Subdural Hematoma (SDH), which is the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura, resulting from the tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the Dural sinuses. It is commonly seen in the elderly, alcoholics, and patients on anticoagulants. The stretching of Cortical-Dural bridging veins in cerebral atrophy makes them vulnerable to rupture, leading to symptoms of raised intracranial pressure or focal deficits. On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped lesion.

 

A subdural hematoma is a collection of blood between the layers of the dura mater surrounding the brain. It can occur as a result of head trauma, such as a fall, and may not present with immediate symptoms but can lead to a gradual onset of neurological symptoms, including headache, confusion, and other focal neurological deficits. Subdural hematomas are known to have delayed presentations after the initial trauma, making this the likely diagnosis in the context of a fall with subsequent neurological symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multi-infarct dementia: Multi-infarct dementia, also known as vascular dementia, typically develops gradually and is associated with a history of multiple strokes or cerebral infarctions. It does not typically present acutely after a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Option B. Frontal lobe meningioma: While a frontal lobe meningioma can cause neurological symptoms, it typically develops slowly and is not usually associated with an acute presentation following a fall. Additionally, the symptoms of a meningioma can vary widely depending on its location and size.

 

Option C. Korsakoff disease: Korsakoff disease is primarily associated with chronic alcohol abuse and is characterized by severe memory impairment. It does not typically present acutely following a fall with neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A patient came with pain in the abdomen and on further imaging the following is obtained. What is the best management option for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteroscopic removal

 

The given X-ray image shows a left lower/distal ureteric stone. Ureteroscopic removal is generally preferred for ureteric stones, specifically those present in the distal ureter.

 

  • This procedure involves passing a small scope directly into the ureter (usually via the bladder) to visualize the stone. Once the stone is located, it can be fragmented (usually with a laser) and the pieces can be removed.
  • Ureteroscopic removal is often preferred for stones located in the distal ureter, especially if they are below 6 mm in size. The advantage of this method is direct visualization and removal of the stone.
  • Potential complications can include ureteric injury, perforation, and subsequent stricture formation, although these are relatively rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy):

 

  • PCNL is an invasive procedure where a tract is created from the skin directly into the kidney. Through this tract, instruments can be inserted to fragment and extract stones.
  • This approach is most commonly used for large renal stones or when other treatments have failed. It's generally not the first-line treatment for a distal ureteric stone.

 

Option B. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy):

 

  • ESWL uses shock waves generated outside the body to fragment stones inside the urinary tract. The fragmented stone pieces can then pass out with urine.
  • ESWL is most suitable for small to medium-sized stones located in the kidney or upper ureter. It is less effective for distal ureteric stones compared to ureteroscopic removal.

 

Option D. Reassurance:

 

  • Some small stones, especially those in the lower ureter, might pass spontaneously. In such cases, if the stone isn't causing obstruction, infection, or severe pain, the patient might be advised to drink plenty of water and wait to see if the stone passes on its own.
  • Pain management and periodic follow-ups would be essential. However, for symptomatic stones, active removal is often preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For symptomatic distal ureteric stones, ureteroscopic removal is typically the best management option due to its effectiveness and minimal invasiveness.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the surgery OPD. On examination, his left scrotal sac is empty. On clinical examination the left testis was found in the superficial inguinal pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left ectopic testis

 

The given condition with left testis being in ectopic location (superficial inguinal pouch) is ectopic testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptorchidism and Option B. Left undescended testis: In undescended testis there is both abnormal development and abnormal location of testis but along the normal path of Descent. It may get spontaneously resolved within 3 months. Till then, the best step should be to wait and watch. Best age for orchidopexy is 6 months and should not be delayed beyond 12 months.

 

Option D. Retractile Testis: Retractile testis has completed the descent but found in groin due to overactive cremasteric reflex, it requires no Treatment and resolves on its own.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ectopic testis refers to a testis that has deviated from the normal path of descent and is located in an abnormal position outside the inguinal canal and scrotum.

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous malignancies does not metastasize through the lymphatics? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is characterized by its inability to metastasize through lymphatic channels. BCC "destroys the lymphatics and vessels" and demonstrates "no lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis." BCCs are locally invasive tumors that produce type IV collagenase (particularly the morphoeic type), which allows them to invade surrounding tissues, but they rarely spread beyond their primary site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma - Incorrect. SCCs and can metastasize through lymphatic channels as part of their natural history. The overall rate of metastasis is 2% for SCC, usually to regional nodes.

 

Option C. Melanoma - Incorrect. Melanoma is highly aggressive and readily metastasizes through lymphatics. The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index in melanoma. The staging of melanoma (TNM) explicitly includes nodal status.

 

Option D. Kaposi's sarcoma - Incorrect. Kaposi's sarcoma is a malignant, proliferative tumor of vascular endothelial cells that can spread through lymphatic channels. It usually starts as a red-brown, indurated, plaque-like skin lesion that becomes nodular and then ulcerates.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Basal cell carcinoma is unique among skin malignancies for its lack of lymphatic metastasis, despite its locally invasive nature through collagenase production.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Closed suction drain

 

The drain shown in the image is a Romovac drain, which is a type of closed suction drain. Closed suction drains are used to remove fluids from a surgical site while maintaining a closed system, preventing contamination and infection. These drains have a bulb or collection reservoir that creates a negative pressure vacuum when compressed, allowing for continuous drainage of fluids from the wound site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open drain: These drains, like Penrose drains, are open systems where fluids drain passively onto a dressing or into a container, which increases the risk of infection due to exposure to the external environment.

 

Option B. Semi-open drain: These drains are a hybrid between open and closed systems, but are not as commonly used as purely open or closed systems.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: This is a type of open drain that allows passive drainage of fluids into the surrounding dressings. It is not connected to any suction mechanism or collection container.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Romovac drain is a closed suction drain that uses a vacuum system to actively remove fluids from a surgical site, reducing the risk of infection and aiding in the healing process.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

choices.text: It is made from cat gut
It is made from rabbit gut
It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis
It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue

questions.text: Which of the following is true about chromic catgut? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is absorbed by enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

 

True. Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture, which means that it gets absorbed by the body over time. The process involves enzymatic degradation (breaking down by enzymes) and phagocytosis by macrophages (special cells that engulf and digest foreign substances, microbes, and cellular debris).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is made from cat gut: While the term "catgut" might suggest that the material is derived from cats, this is a misnomer. Catgut suture material is historically derived from the submucosal layer of sheep or goat intestines. The term is a shortened version of the word "cattlegut."

 

Option B. It is made from rabbit gut: This statement is also misleading. As mentioned, the primary sources for catgut are sheep and goat intestines, not rabbit.

 

Option D. It is tanned with nickel salts to improve handling and to resist degradation in tissue: This statement is inaccurate in the context of chromic catgut. Chromic catgut is treated with chromium salts, not nickel salts. Chromium salts are used to cross-link the collagen fibers in the catgut, which increases its resistance to degradation, thus prolonging its time before being absorbed in the tissue. This treatment also improves the suture's handling properties.

 

Educational Objective:


Chromic catgut is an absorbable suture material derived from sheep or goat intestines and is absorbed in the body through enzymatic degradation and macrophage phagocytosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is > 70mm

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG abdomen. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm

 

Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm: True. Generally, surgery (either open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic male patients when the AAA reaches a diameter of 5.5 cm (55mm) or greater. The risk of rupture increases significantly as the diameter surpasses this threshold, so this is the currently accepted cutoff for intervention in many guidelines.

 

Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

 

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size <55mm.

 

Other Options:

 

The size of an AAA determines the risk of rupture, and this risk informs the decision for surgical intervention.

 

Option A. Urgent endovascular aneurysm repair: Not necessarily true for a 40mm AAA. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is a less invasive method than open surgery, but it is not typically done urgently for aneurysms of this size unless they are symptomatic or rapidly increasing in size.

 

Option C. Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery: Not true for a 40mm AAA. As the aneurysm is still below the general threshold for surgical intervention, there's no need for urgent operation unless there are other complicating factors (e.g., rapid growth or symptoms).

 

Option D. Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >70mm: Not true. Waiting for an AAA to reach 70mm before considering surgery would expose the patient to a very high risk of rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgery (open surgical repair or EVAR) is recommended for asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysms when the diameter reaches 55mm or greater due to the increased risk of rupture beyond this size. Regular monitoring is advised for smaller aneurysms.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthur’s incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident presents with bradycardia and hypertension. On examination, the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is found to be less than 8. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intubate and ventilation

 

The patient presents with bradycardia and hypertension, indicating raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to a head injury. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of less than 8 signifies a severe head injury with significantly impaired consciousness. In such cases, the next critical step is to secure the airway through intubation and provide ventilation.

 

Intubation is crucial in this scenario for several reasons:
