  • Airway protection: With a GCS below 8, the patient is at high risk of airway obstruction due to a lack of protective reflexes. Intubation ensures the airway remains open.
  • Reducing ICP: Positive pressure ventilation at a higher rate can help reduce intracranial pressure by decreasing CO2 levels and inducing cerebral vasoconstriction.
  • Protection from aspiration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urgent CT head: This is an important step but comes after securing the airway and stabilizing the patient.

 

Option C. Thrombolysis: This is incorrect as it is used for conditions such as stroke or myocardial infarction, not for managing raised ICP in trauma patients.

 

Option D. Saline: This is incorrect as administering saline does not address the immediate need to secure the airway and manage raised ICP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a GCS score less than 8, the immediate step is to intubate and ventilate to secure the airway and manage raised intracranial pressure.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

 

Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) scoring system:

 

Other Options:

 

It uses three criteria, assigning one point each for:

 

Option A. Altered mental status

 

Option B. Low blood pressure (SBP < 100 mmHg)

 

Option C. High respiratory rate (>22 breaths per min)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.

 

The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.

 

The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.

 

The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

questions.text: Which of these classifications of bile duct injury takes into account the location of injury, and thermal and vascular injury to bile ducts? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hannover 

 

  • When discussing bile duct injuries, several classification systems have been developed to categorize these injuries based on their nature, location, and the extent of damage. 

 

This system categorizes bile duct injuries based on the anatomical structure involved and the extent of the injury, including vascular injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bismuth Classification: Primarily focuses on the location of the bile duct injury in relation to the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. This classification is widely used to describe bile duct injuries post-cholecystectomy.

 

Option B. Strassberg Classification (also known as the Strassberg-Bismuth classification): This is an extension of the Bismuth classification, adding more detail and incorporating the critical view of safety concept. It includes acute injuries, but it is based on location alone. Associated vascular injuries are not included.

 

Option C. Stewart-Way Classification: This classification focuses on the phase of the operation in which the injury occurs and the type of injury, including thermal damage. It categorizes injuries into four types:

 

  1. Type I: Cystic duct leak or leakage from a small peripheral hepatic radicle close to the gallbladder fossa.
  2. Type II: Injury to the main bile duct that does not involve excision, typically a lateral injury.
  3. Type III: Complete transaction or excision of a segment of the main bile duct.
  4. Type IV: Injury involving damage to the hepatic duct confluence and bifurcation.

 

Stewart-Way classification does not account for associated vascular injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bismuth and Strassberg classifications are anatomically based classifications of bile duct injury.

questions.text: Image a of child with an orofacial cleft as shown. When is the first repair done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 months

 

The initial repair for cleft lip is typically performed at around 3 months of age. According to Millard's Rule of 10, the surgery is ideally done when the infant is at least 10 weeks old, weighs around 10 pounds (approximately 4.5 kilograms), and has a hemoglobin level of 10 grams per deciliter. This timing helps ensure the child is sufficiently mature and robust for surgery, minimizing surgical risks and optimizing healing.

 

Repair of the cleft lip/nose and anterior palate generally occurs between 3 to 6 months of age, while definitive repair of the cleft palate is typically performed between 6 and 12 months of age, as outlined in the provided reference.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 months: This is the general timeframe for repairing the soft palate but is not the earliest repair. For cleft lip, the first repair usually happens earlier, at around 3 months.

 

Option C. 12 months: This is more appropriate for the repair of the hard palate and definitive palate repair, not the initial cleft lip repair.

 

Option D. 2 years: This timing is not typically relevant for the first repair of cleft lip or palate and is much later than the standard recommendations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first repair of cleft lip is typically done at around 3 months of age, following the Millard's Rule of 10, to optimize surgical outcomes and ensure the infant is prepared for the procedure.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition characterized by the abnormal development of the bladder and lower abdominal wall, resulting in the bladder being exposed outside the body. The image shows a typical presentation of bladder exstrophy, with the bladder visible as a red mass on the lower abdomen of the newborn. This condition requires surgical correction to reconstruct the bladder and close the abdominal wall defect.

 

Other Options:

 

Open A. Umbilical hernia: An umbilical hernia is characterized by the protrusion of abdominal contents through an opening in the abdominal muscles near the umbilicus. It typically presents as a soft bulge near the belly button, which is reducible and covered by skin, differing from the exposed bladder seen in bladder exstrophy.

 

Open B. Omphalocele: Omphalocele is a congenital defect where the abdominal contents, such as intestines, liver, and other organs, herniate through the base of the umbilical cord and are covered by a protective membrane. It does not involve exposure of the bladder and is distinct from bladder exstrophy.

 

Option D. Gastroschisis: It is an abdominal wall defect where intestines are protruding, but lack a peritoneal covering. The defect is usually to the right side of umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy presents with the bladder exposed outside the abdominal wall, requiring prompt surgical intervention to correct the defect and reconstruct the urinary tract.

choices.text: Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign
Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer
Median age of survival is 6 months in all cases

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. She was diagnosed with cholecystitis and cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. The post-operative biopsy reports came back positive for gallbladder carcinoma. What is true about gallbladder carcinoma? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clinical presentation of gall stones can sometimes be distinguished from gall bladder cancer

 

This statement is correct. The clinical presentation of gallstones (cholelithiasis) and gallbladder cancer (carcinoma) can sometimes be distinguished. Gallstones commonly cause symptoms such as biliary colic (episodic, severe right upper quadrant pain) and may lead to acute cholecystitis, which includes symptoms like pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In contrast, gallbladder carcinoma may present with more persistent or progressive symptoms, including unexplained weight loss and, in some cases, a palpable abdominal mass. The two conditions can have overlapping symptoms, but their clinical courses can be distinguished based on the duration and progression of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palpable abdominal lump is the earliest sign: This statement is not true. A palpable abdominal lump is not typically the earliest sign of gallbladder carcinoma. Gallbladder carcinoma often presents with nonspecific symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. As the cancer progresses, it may cause other symptoms, but a palpable lump is usually a late finding.

 

Option B. Earliest sign is jaundice: This statement is also not true for most cases of gallbladder carcinoma. Jaundice is more commonly associated with cancers of the bile ducts (cholangiocarcinoma) or pancreatic cancer when the tumor obstructs the bile ducts. While gallbladder carcinoma can cause jaundice if it obstructs the common bile duct, it is not typically the earliest sign of the disease.

 

Option D. Median age of survival is 6 months: This statement is not accurate for all cases of gallbladder carcinoma. The survival rate for gallbladder carcinoma can vary widely depending on factors such as the stage at diagnosis and the extent of surgical resection. While some cases have a poor prognosis with a short median survival, others may have a better outcome if diagnosed at an earlier stage and treated appropriately.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Option C is correct because gallstones and gallbladder carcinoma often have distinct clinical presentations, allowing them to be distinguished from each other.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency room with a history of a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient is found to have shock and hypotension. Extended focused assessment with sonography for trauma (eFAST) is negative. X-ray is normal, and ECG shows no abnormalities. The SpO2 is 93%, and the blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg with a pulse rate of 80/min. What type shock is most likely present? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neurogenic shock

 

Neurogenic shock results from disruption of sympathetic tone, often due to spinal cord injury or severe head injury. It is characterized by distributive shock with bradycardia and hypotension despite adequate intravascular volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic shock: Anaphylactic shock typically presents with symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema, bronchospasm, and hypotension following exposure to an allergen. It is characterized by distributive shock due to widespread vasodilation and increased vascular permeability.

 

Option B. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from acute blood loss, leading to decreased circulating volume and impaired tissue perfusion. It is characterized by hypovolemic shock, often with tachycardia, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output.

 

Option C. Cardiogenic shock: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to cardiac pump failure, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion. It is characterized by signs of low cardiac output, such as hypotension, tachycardia, pulmonary congestion, and altered mental status.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a trauma patient with hypotension, negative eFAST, and no evidence of hemorrhage or cardiac dysfunction, neurogenic shock should be considered, especially in the context of spinal cord injury or severe head injury.

questions.text: Given the image showing significant limb swelling, which body system is likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lymphatics

 

The image shows significant swelling of the limb, particularly in the calf region, with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance. This presentation is indicative of lymphedema, which is a condition resulting from impairment of the lymphatic system. The swelling, shape, and involvement of the foot and toes (squaring of toes) are classic features of lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Artery: Arterial involvement would typically cause limb wasting rather than swelling, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Vein: Venous involvement would present as varicose veins, which are not seen in the image, ruling out this option.

 

Option D. Muscle: Muscular involvement does not present in the characteristic way shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Significant limb swelling with a characteristic "tree trunk" appearance in the calf region, along with swelling of the foot and squaring of the toes, is a classic presentation of lymphedema, suggesting involvement of the lymphatic system.

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

 

The typhoid vaccine is typically not recommended before splenectomy in a child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism. Typhoid vaccination may lead to a transient decrease in platelet count, which can exacerbate the existing hypersplenism and increase the risk of bleeding. Therefore, it is often deferred until after splenectomy when the risk of post-vaccination thrombocytopenia is reduced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumococcal vaccine: The pneumococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia (absence of the spleen) or hyposplenism (reduced spleen function) because they are at an increased risk of severe infections, including those caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the pneumococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenza B vaccine: The Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine is recommended as part of routine childhood immunization and does not have specific contraindications related to hereditary spherocytosis or splenectomy.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: The meningococcal vaccine is recommended for individuals with asplenia or hyposplenism, as they are at an increased risk of meningococcal infections. However, for individuals with hereditary spherocytosis who have an intact spleen, the meningococcal vaccine may be administered as part of routine immunization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below used in laparoscopic surgeries? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The instrument in the image is Veress Needle.

 

The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries. It consists of a long, slender needle with a sharp, pointed tip and a hollow center. The needle is attached to a handle and a valve that controls the flow of gas into the abdominal cavity.

 

The Veress needle is inserted into the abdominal cavity through a small incision, usually in the umbilicus (closed technique). The surgeon first lifts the abdominal wall away from the underlying organs and tissues, then inserts the Veress needle at a 45-degree angle to the skin and advances it until it reaches the abdominal cavity. The valve is then opened to allow gas (usually carbon dioxide) to flow into the abdominal cavity, creating a space for the laparoscope and other instruments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morris' needle: This is not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum or laparoscopic access.

 

Option C. Yankauer suction tip: This is a suction instrument used to clear surgical sites of blood and fluids, not for gas insufflation.

 

Option D. Von Graefe needle: Primarily used in ophthalmic procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of the Veress needle helps to minimize the risk of injury to surrounding organs and tissues during laparoscopic procedures. It is typically used at the beginning of the procedure, after which the laparoscope and other instruments are inserted through separate ports or trocars placed in the abdomen. The Veress needle is then removed and the incision closed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

 

  • The spread of prostate carcinoma to the lumbar vertebrae is primarily through the prostatic venous plexus or Bateson plexus. Tumor cells spread to the spine and proximal long bones via Bateson's venous plexus, which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.
  • The prostatic venous plexus (or Bateson plexus) is a network of veins surrounding the prostate.
  • The prostatic venous plexus has connections to the internal vertebral venous plexuses.
  • Because of this unique venous anatomy, tumor cells from the prostate can enter the venous system and bypass the usual portal and caval routes, spreading directly to the spine, specifically the lumbar vertebrae.
  • This is the most common route for metastasis of prostate cancer to the spine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans coelomic spread: Trans coelomic spread refers to the dissemination of malignant cells across body cavities, such as the pleural, peritoneal, or pericardial spaces. This method of spread is most commonly seen with primary cancers of the ovary, stomach, and colon. In the context of prostate cancer, trans coelomic spread is not a typical route to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Option C. Inferior vesical vein: The inferior vesical vein drains the urinary bladder. While there are venous communications between the prostatic plexus and the vesical veins, the direct spread of prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae through the inferior vesical vein alone is less common than through the prostatic venous plexus.

 

Option D. Internal iliac vein: The internal iliac vein drains blood from the pelvis and perineum. While prostate cancer can spread through the internal iliac vein as part of its venous drainage, this route is not the primary pathway to the lumbar vertebrae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical wall repair 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital condition where the baby is born with the intestines located outside of the body through an opening in the abdominal wall. 

 

This is the most appropriate management strategy. It involves surgical correction where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdominal cavity and the abdominal wall defect is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This is not an appropriate strategy for gastroschisis. Without prompt surgical intervention, the exposed intestines are at risk of infection, dehydration, and injury.

 

Option C. Slowly putting it inside: While the concept of gradually reducing the bowel back into the abdominal cavity (sometimes called "silo" reduction) is a valid approach, it is performed as part of the surgical management and under controlled conditions, not as a standalone treatment.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This option is not relevant to the management of gastroschisis. There is no need to excise the bowel unless there is nonviable tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management for a neonate with gastroschisis is immediate surgical repair to return the intestines to the abdominal cavity and close the defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland, which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lingual nerve

 

A ranula is a type of mucocele found on the floor of the mouth, associated with the sublingual gland. During the surgical excision of a ranula along with the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is at risk of being injured. The lingual nerve runs close to the sublingual gland and is responsible for sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Due to its proximity, it is the structure most likely to be damaged during such surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mylohyoid muscle: The mylohyoid muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is situated below the sublingual gland. It is less likely to be injured during the excision of a ranula as the procedure primarily involves the tissues above this muscle.

 

Option C. Submental artery: The submental artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the mylohyoid muscle. While it is in the general area, it is not as closely associated with the sublingual gland as the lingual nerve is, making it less likely to be injured during this specific procedure.

 

Option D. Sublingual artery: The sublingual artery supplies blood to the sublingual gland and the surrounding tissues. Although it is close to the surgical site, the risk of injury to the lingual nerve is higher due to its course and proximity to the gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During the excision of a ranula and the sublingual gland, the lingual nerve is the structure most likely to be injured due to its anatomical position relative to the sublingual gland. This nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and its injury can result in significant sensory deficits.
